text:
The problem is that "X/*" URL mask matches "X" under tomcat, but not in mod_jk. 
Such a difference b/w matching algorithms makes it more difficult to configure 
mod_jk based on the web.xml.
For example you have a servlet-url mapping: MyServlet1 -> /MyServlet1/* in 
web.xml of application "app1". When you access app1 directly through tomcat, 
following URL-s are mapped to the 
MyServlet1: "/app1/MyServlet1", "/app1/MyServlet1/child", etc. 
If you map servlet using JkMount in the form: "JkMount /app1/MyServlet1/* 
MyWorker" and will try to access the same URL-s via mod_jk, 
URL "/app1/MyServlet1" will not be accessible, b/c mod_jk will not match this 
URL to the specified JkMount mapping.
creator: dvoytenko@reveredata.com

text:
I wonder if this is similar to a problem I have. Using Tomcat directly I can
access a webapp that is titled JSPWiki by going to http://url:8080/JSPWiki,
however if I try via JkMount it will fail to connect even though it found a match.

However if I renamed the webapp to jspwiki I can access it through Tomcat
directly and via mod_jk.
creator: rob@tarasis.net
mturk@apache.org
text:
Use:

JkMount /app1/MyServlet1|/* MyWorker
as a convinience method for matching both
/app1/MyServlet1
and
/app1/MyServlet1/*

Hi Mladen Turk,

Thanks for that but I find it doesn't work for me when using Tomcat 5.5.12,
Mod_jk 1.2.15, Apache 2.0.54.

using JkMount /jsp-examples works, using JkMount /JSPWiki doesn't. Renaming
JSPWiki to jspwiki and using JkMount /jspwiki works.
creator: rob@tarasis.net
mturk@apache.org
text:
Right.

The problem is that mod_jk needs to follow the common
denominator of the web server, not servlet-api.
Many OS-es does not allow case sensitivity, so the lowrecase
is that common denomitator.
It is something that you'll have to live with :)
